affiliations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research

children.value: In numerical weather prediction and climate modeling, time stepping refers to the process of advancing the simulation in time. This is typically done by discretizing the time domain into small intervals, or “time steps,” and updating the state of the system at each time step based on the governing equations.
There are several methods for time stepping, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. This section is a reference of the most commonly used algorithms.
Given an equation for the tendency of a random variable

children.html: ∂u∂t=Q(t,u)\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = Q(t,u)∂t∂u​=Q(t,u)

children.value: These methods are used to approximate the solution to a differential equation by starting at an initial point and taking a series of small, discrete steps forward in time.

children.label: euler_explicit
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+ΔtQτ\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \Delta t Q^\tauu~τ+1=u~τ+ΔtQτ
Δt\Delta tΔt

children.label: euler_implicit
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+ΔtQτ+1\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \Delta t Q^{\tau+1}u~τ+1=u~τ+ΔtQτ+1
Δt\Delta tΔt

children.label: euler_trapezoidal
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt2(Qτ+Qτ+1)\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}(Q^\tau + Q^{\tau+1})u~τ+1=u~τ+2Δt​(Qτ+Qτ+1)
Δt2\Delta t^2Δt2

children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt((1−α)Qτ+αQτ+1)\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \Delta t((1-\alpha)Q^\tau + \alpha Q^{\tau+1})u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt((1−α)Qτ+αQτ+1)
Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: This is a flexible framework that combines the explicit and implicit methods using a weighting factor,

children.html: α\alphaα
α=0\alpha=0α=0

children.value: , it is the fully explicit method.

children.html: α=1\alpha=1α=1

children.value: , it is the fully implicit method.

children.html: α=0.5\alpha=0.5α=0.5

children.value: This allows for a tunable balance between the computational ease of the explicit method and the stability of the implicit method.
Unlike single-step methods that only use information from the most recent time step, multistep methods increase accuracy by using information from several previous steps to compute the next step.

children.label: leapfrog
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ−1+2ΔtQτ\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^{\tau-1} + 2\Delta t Q^\tauu~τ+1=u~τ−1+2ΔtQτ
Δt2\Delta t^2Δt2

children.label: adams_bashforth
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt2(−Qτ−1+3Qτ)\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}(-Q^{\tau-1} + 3Q^\tau)u~τ+1=u~τ+2Δt​(−Qτ−1+3Qτ)
Δt2\Delta t^2Δt2

children.label: adams_moulton
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt12(−Qτ−1+8Qτ+5Qτ+1)\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{12}(-Q^{\tau-1} + 8Q^\tau + 5Q^{\tau+1})u~τ+1=u~τ+12Δt​(−Qτ−1+8Qτ+5Qτ+1)
Δt3\Delta t^3Δt3

children.label: adams_bashforth_2
children.html: u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt12(5Qτ−2−16Qτ−1+23Qτ+1)\tilde{u}^{\tau+1} = \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{12}(5Q^{\tau-2} - 16Q^{\tau-1} + 23Q^{\tau+1})u~τ+1=u~τ+12Δt​(5Qτ−2−16Qτ−1+23Qτ+1)
Δt3\Delta t^3Δt3

children.value: The leapfrog method is an explicit, second-order method that is popular for simulating physical systems. It gets its name because it “leaps” over the current point (

children.html: uτu^\tauuτ
uτ+1u^{\tau+1}uτ+1
uτu^\tauuτ

children.value: and the value from the previous point,

children.html: uτ−1u^{\tau-1}uτ−1

children.value: . This structure helps conserve energy in long-term simulations but can sometimes lead to instability.

Multistage methods calculate the solution at the next time step by performing several intermediate calculations, or “stages,” within a single time interval. Instead of using data from previous time steps (like multistep methods), they evaluate the derivative function multiple times
the current and next points to get a more accurate slope estimate.
The core idea is to take a “trial” step, re-evaluate the derivative at this new trial position, and then use this more accurate information to take the final, full step.

, this scheme first takes a half-step to the midpoint of the time interval. It then uses the derivative calculated at that midpoint to compute the full step, which is more accurate than just using the derivative from the start of the interval.

This is one of the most widely used numerical methods for solving differential equations. It achieves very high accuracy by cleverly performing four derivative evaluations within each time step: one at the beginning, two at the midpoint, and one at the end of the interval. These are combined in a weighted average to produce a result that is remarkably accurate and robust.

children.label: rk2
children.html: u~τ+1/2=u~τ+Δt2Q(tτ,u~τ)u~τ+1=u~τ+ΔtQ(tτ+1/2,u~τ+1/2)\begin{aligned} \tilde{u}^{\tau+1/2} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}Q(t^\tau, \tilde{u}^\tau) \\ \tilde{u}^{\tau+1} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \Delta t Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}^{\tau+1/2}) \end{aligned}u~τ+1/2u~τ+1​=u~τ+2Δt​Q(tτ,u~τ)=u~τ+ΔtQ(tτ+1/2,u~τ+1/2)​
Δt2\Delta t^2Δt2

children.value: \begin{aligned} \tilde{u}_a^{\tau+1/2} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}Q(t^\tau, \tilde{u}^\tau) \\ \tilde{u}_b^{\tau+1/2} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_a^{\tau+1/2}) \\ \tilde{u}^* &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \Delta t Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_b^{\tau+1/2}) \\ \tilde{u}^{\tau+1} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{6} \big( Q(t^\tau, \tilde{u}^\tau) + 2Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_a^{\tau+1/2}) \\ &+ 2Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_b^{\tau+1/2}) + Q(t^{\tau+1}, \tilde{u}^*) \big) \end{aligned}
children.label: rk4
children.html: u~aτ+1/2=u~τ+Δt2Q(tτ,u~τ)u~bτ+1/2=u~τ+Δt2Q(tτ+1/2,u~aτ+1/2)u~∗=u~τ+ΔtQ(tτ+1/2,u~bτ+1/2)u~τ+1=u~τ+Δt6(Q(tτ,u~τ)+2Q(tτ+1/2,u~aτ+1/2)+2Q(tτ+1/2,u~bτ+1/2)+Q(tτ+1,u~∗))\begin{aligned} \tilde{u}_a^{\tau+1/2} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}Q(t^\tau, \tilde{u}^\tau) \\ \tilde{u}_b^{\tau+1/2} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{2}Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_a^{\tau+1/2}) \\ \tilde{u}^* &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \Delta t Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_b^{\tau+1/2}) \\ \tilde{u}^{\tau+1} &= \tilde{u}^\tau + \frac{\Delta t}{6} \big( Q(t^\tau, \tilde{u}^\tau) + 2Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_a^{\tau+1/2}) \\ &+ 2Q(t^{\tau+1/2}, \tilde{u}_b^{\tau+1/2}) + Q(t^{\tau+1}, \tilde{u}^*) \big) \end{aligned}u~aτ+1/2​u~bτ+1/2​u~∗u~τ+1​=u~τ+2Δt​Q(tτ,u~τ)=u~τ+2Δt​Q(tτ+1/2,u~aτ+1/2​)=u~τ+ΔtQ(tτ+1/2,u~bτ+1/2​)=u~τ+6Δt​(Q(tτ,u~τ)+2Q(tτ+1/2,u~aτ+1/2​)+2Q(tτ+1/2,u~bτ+1/2​)+Q(tτ+1,u~∗))​
Δt4\Delta t^4Δt4
